block.p: INTERNATIONAL
Negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers were endorsed by House and Senate panels. [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY
Retail sales rose 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Dept. said, revising figures that had shown an 0.8 percent drop. The gain was viewed as a sign that the economic slide is halting. [ A1. ]
INTERNATIONAL
Negotiations for a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a new round of lowering of international trade barriers were endorsed by House and Senate panels. [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY
Retail sales rose 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Dept. said, revising figures that had shown an 0.8 percent drop. The gain was viewed as a sign that the economic slide is halting. [ A1. ]
A House panel rejected Administration proposals to limit coverage of bank deposit insurance. [ D1. ]
Consumer prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in April despite a sharp jump in food costs, the Government reported. [ D6. ]
Sales fell 18.3 percent in early May for cars and light trucks made in the U.S. and Canada. [ D6. ]
The Municipal Assistance Corp. will give New York City $1 billion under certain conditions, Rohatyn said. [ A1. ] COMPANIES
Carl Icahn apparently sold his holdings in USX, ending a long and tempestuous relationship. [ D1. ]
The F.D.A. assailed three large food concerns, including Procter & Gamble, over labeling of low-cholesterol foods. [ D1. ]

Regulators seized First Capital Holdings' California insurance subsidiary after Citibank tried to force a bankruptcy proceeding. [ D1. ] Wall Street firms are scrambling to calm clients who purchased insurance policies through the brokerages. [ D6. ]
Electronics companies are moving rapidly to phase out industrial cleansers known to damage the ozone layer. [ D1. ]
The search for a successor to Marvin S. Traub at Bloomingdale's has reportedly been narrowed to two finalists. [ D4. ]
Businessland said it had been cut off by one of its key lenders and might have to seek bankruptcy protection. [ D5. ]
Digital Equipment will market personal computers made by Intel and Olivetti, Digital's president said. [ D5. ]
Exxon said it had made a potentially large oil and gas discovery in the Gulf of Mexico. Conoco holds a 50 percent interest. [ D4. ]
For the first time, surgeons have implanted a fully portable, mechanical device to help a patient's failing heart. [ A18. ]
Sanford I. Weill will become chairman of Carnegie Hall, replacing James D. Wolfensohn. [ C11. ] BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
Computer-aided product design is no longer the exclusive province of engineers and technicians. [ D1. ]
Researchers at Bell Labs said they had invented a new form of brass that could be used in faucets to help reduce lead. [ D7. ] MARKETS
Stocks plunged in sympathy with a depressed bond market. The Dow fell 37.57, to 2,886.85. [ D8. ]
Treasury bond prices tumbled, as a favorable report on inflation was not enough to overcome news on retail sales. [ D17. ]
Prices of cotton futures bounded higher on speculation that shortages could develop. [ D18. ] The dollar fell. [ D18. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS
The fight to open the border with Mexico is a diversion, one economist argues. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
At Moore Medical, a dissident shareholder is waging an unlikely proxy fight. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ]
Direct marketers will honor a man who has used their often-derided medium for uncommon persuasive purposes. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D20. ]
